title: Setup CI builds for Linux and MacOS apps
body:
The branch that currently works is [`macos-packaging-refactor`](https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/tree/chore/macos-packaging-refactor).
Apparently calling `make macos` should Just Workâ„¢.

We'll also need a setup on Jenkins to securely sign the app using a Keychain.

I have a two jobs here:

* https://ci.status.im/job/nim-status-client/job/linux/
* https://ci.status.im/job/nim-status-client/job/macos/

The work is happening in the [`ci-setup`](https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/tree/ci-setup) branch.

### Linux Notes

* Using Nix works, but getting the old `2.23` GLibc version would rebuild too much stuff to be feasible
* `a12e/docker-qt:5.14-gcc_64` docker image used in [`build-linux.sh`](https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/blob/master/build-linux.sh) is a good starting point
* With minimal adjustments I made a [`Dockerfile`](https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/blob/ci-setup/ci/Dockerfile) based off of it and pushed a [`nim-status-client-build`](https://hub.docker.com/r/statusteam/nim-status-client-build) image
* Use of `linuxdeployqt` fails with `fuse: mount failed: Permission denied` because of Docker user remapping
  - Adding of `--cap-add SYS_ADMIN --device /dev/fuse` fixes lack of `/dev/fuse` initially
* A `jenkins` user has to exist in the image with UID/GID set to `1001` due to how our hosts are set up

### MacOS Notes

* The installer DMG file for Qt cannot be installed without UI, but it's possible to tarball the resulting installation for CI setup
* I deployed a tarball like that in https://github.com/status-im/infra-ci/commit/314fc2d8 to all 3 CI hosts
* The `pkg-config` and `wget` packages need to be installed via Homebrew

I'm having a weird warnings on MacOS during build:
```
11:35:50  Package Qt5Core was not found in the pkg-config search path.
11:35:50  Perhaps you should add the directory containing `Qt5Core.pc'
11:35:50  to the PKG_CONFIG_PATH environment variable
11:35:50  No package 'Qt5Core' found
11:35:50  Package Qt5Qml was not found in the pkg-config search path.
11:35:50  Perhaps you should add the directory containing `Qt5Qml.pc'
11:35:50  to the PKG_CONFIG_PATH environment variable
11:35:50  No package 'Qt5Qml' found
11:35:50  Package Qt5Gui was not found in the pkg-config search path.
11:35:50  Perhaps you should add the directory containing `Qt5Gui.pc'
11:35:50  to the PKG_CONFIG_PATH environment variable
11:35:50  No package 'Qt5Gui' found
...
```
Although as far as I can tell I have a valid Qt installation.
Looks like using the [online Qt installer](http://download.qt.io/official_releases/online_installers/qt-unified-mac-x64-online.dmg) gives a more complete installation for some reason...
Also, the `QTDIR` needs to be set so that at it's root there's the architecture folder, like `gcc_64` or `clang_64`.

In order to fix the issues with Fuse permissions for Linux builds I might have to disable  [user remapping](https://docs.docker.com/engine/security/userns-remap/) for Docker on our hosts:
```
12:54:53  linuxdeployqt tmp/linux/dist/nim-status.desktop -no-translations -no-copy-copyright-files -qmldir=tmp/linux/dist/usr/ui -qmlimport=/opt/qt/5.14.0/gcc_64/qml -bundle-non-qt-libs
12:54:53  fuse: mount failed: Permission denied
12:54:53  open dir error: No such file or directory
12:54:53  Makefile:170: recipe for target 'pkg/NimStatusClient-x86_64.AppImage' failed
```
Which might be a pain because other jobs that use Docker might take that into account.
Although the only ones I can think of right now are [`status-go`](https://ci.status.im/job/status-go/job/platforms/job/xgo/) and [`keycard-cli`](https://ci.status.im/job/status-keycard/job/keycard-cli/) ones.

And it appears that `QT5_PCFILEDIR` and `QT5_LIBDIR` have to be set for `cmake` to detect Qt correctly:
```
13:06:07  CMake Warning at lib/CMakeLists.txt:7 (find_package):
13:06:07    By not providing "FindQt5.cmake" in CMAKE_MODULE_PATH this project has
13:06:07    asked CMake to find a package configuration file provided by "Qt5", but
13:06:07    CMake did not find one.
13:06:07  
13:06:07    Could not find a package configuration file provided by "Qt5" with any of
13:06:07    the following names:
13:06:07  
13:06:07      Qt5Config.cmake
13:06:07      qt5-config.cmake
13:06:07  
13:06:07    Add the installation prefix of "Qt5" to CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH or set "Qt5_DIR"
13:06:07    to a directory containing one of the above files.  If "Qt5" provides a
13:06:07    separate development package or SDK, be sure it has been installed.
13:06:07  Call Stack (most recent call first):
13:06:07    lib/CMakeLists.txt:71 (add_target)
```

I'm really confused by behavior of 2 MacOS hosts.
On `macos-03.ms-eu-dublin.ci.misc` setting `QTDIR=/usr/local/qt` is enough to `make nim_status_client`.
But on `macos-01.ms-eu-dublin.ci.misc` using the same `QTDIR=/usr/local/qt` results in a failure, sometimes. But setting it to `QTDIR=/usr/local/qt/clang_64` unblocks that failure for no good reason.

First successful MacOS build: https://ci.status.im/job/nim-status-client/job/macos/25
Except it's not actually successful, just that the failure is not registered:
```
16:26:12  âœ– Code signing failed. The DMG is fine, just not code signed.
16:26:12  No suitable code signing identity found
```
No next step is to get the keystore into Jenkins.

It might be possible to create a keychain with the certificate using CLI:
```
sudo security add-trusted-cert -d -r trustRoot -k /Library/Keychains/System.keychain <certificate>
```
https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/80623/import-certificates-into-the-system-keychain-via-the-command-line

Almost there:
```
17:57:04  ERROR: Could not parse otool output line: "\t/System/Library/Frameworks/MediaPlayer.framework/Versions/A/MediaPlayer (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0, weak)"
17:57:05  ERROR: Could not parse otool output line: "\t/System/Library/Frameworks/MediaPlayer.framework/Versions/A/MediaPlayer (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0, weak)"
17:57:05  ERROR: Could not parse otool output line: "\t/System/Library/Frameworks/MediaPlayer.framework/Versions/A/MediaPlayer (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0, weak)"
17:57:07  ERROR: Could not parse otool output line: "\t/System/Library/Frameworks/MediaPlayer.framework/Versions/A/MediaPlayer (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0, weak)"
17:57:12  ****: no identity found
17:57:12  make: *** [pkg/Status.dmg] Error 1
```
It appears I might need both the private key and the cert in the keychain to make it work.

Yes, it looks like the best bet would be to:

1. Create a new Keychain
2. Create a new private key in that Keychain
3. Generate a CSR from that private key
4. Issue a new MacOS app signing certificate
5. Add that certificate to the Keychain

And then upload that Keychain to our CI credentials.
I'll do that tomorrow. I'll need to document the process too.

I created a new keychain and uploaded it to CI master, even made instructions on how I did it:
https://github.com/status-im/infra-docs/blob/master/articles/macos_signing_keychain.md
But for some reason I'm still getting:
```
 > codesign --sign "${IDENTITY_NAME}" \
      --keychain ~/nim-status-client.keychain-db \
      --options runtime --deep --force --verbose=4 \
      tmp/macos/dist/Status.app
Developer ID Application: STATUS HOLDINGS PTE. LTD. (DTX7Z4U3YA): no identity found
```

Okay, I see what was missing. I need to add the keychain to the search list too:
```
security list-keychains -s ${MACOS_KEYCHAIN_FILE}
```
But now it fails with:
```
fatal error: /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin/codesign_allocate: can't allocate code signature data for: /Users/jenkins/workspace/nim-status-client/macos/tmp/macos/dist/Status.app/Contents/MacOS/nim_status_client (for architecture x86_64) because larger updated load commands do not fit (the program must be relinked using a larger -headerpad value)
tmp/macos/dist/Status.app: the codesign_allocate helper tool cannot be found or used
In subcomponent: /Users/jenkins/workspace/nim-status-client/macos/tmp/macos/dist/Status.app/Contents/MacOS/nim_status_client
```
Which is progress of a kind.

Not to self, `linuxdeployqt` has a `-unsupported-bundle-everything` flag which could let use use newer `glibc` while we work.

* https://github.com/probonopd/linuxdeployqt/issues/423
* https://github.com/probonopd/linuxdeployqt/issues/417

Also this is a possibility: https://github.com/wheybags/glibc_version_header

I tried setting `LDFLAGS=""` to fix the error:
```
codesign_allocate: can't allocate code signature data for: nim_status_client (for architecture x86_64) because larger updated load commands do not fit (the program must be relinked using a larger -headerpad value)
```
But it didn't seem to work, but I found this:
>Will only be used by CMake on the first configuration to determine the default linker flags, after which the value for LDFLAGS is stored in the cache
https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.10/envvar/LDFLAGS.html
It might make sense to upgrade XCode from `11.4.1` to `11.5` just to make sure that's not the issue. I'll do that tomorrow.

Here's an interesting issues that go more in-depth about the `can't allocate code signature data for` error:
* https://trac.macports.org/ticket/39221
* https://trac.sagemath.org/ticket/19698
* https://trac.sagemath.org/ticket/22228
I ran the build on the one `macos-01` I upgraded to XCode `11.5` and the same error happens.
Another thing to try is instead of using `LDFLAGS` I could use `--passL:"-headerpad_max_install_names"` to try to give the suggested linker flag directly to `nim` compiler.

So I've confirmed the flag actually work by setting it directly in the makefile:
```Makefile
NIM_PARAMS += --passL:"-headerpad_max_install_names"
```
And it worked in: https://ci.status.im/job/nim-status-client/job/macos/74/console
Now we have our good old friend `errSecInternalComponent`:
```
### Signing target...
tmp/macos/dist/Status.app: errSecInternalComponent
In subcomponent: /Users/jenkins/workspace/nim-status-client/macos/tmp/macos/dist/Status.app/Contents/MacOS/nim_status_client
```

I think this line is the issue:
https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/blob/7489a2ae0036aeaf4452ace44a81ebb65f7e29eb/Makefile#L97-L99
What it should look like is:
```Makefile
ifeq ($(detected_OS), Darwin)
NIM_PARAMS += -L:"-framework Foundation -framework Security -framework IOKit -framework CoreServices"
endif
```
Otherwise the value from the environment is not inherited properly.

NIM_PARAMS should not be in the environment. That's NIMFLAGS territory.

The former is just a set of hidden-from-the-user options that the latter can add to: https://github.com/status-im/nimbus-build-system#nimflags

Why would you split those? What's the point? In a `Makefile` you can just append to an existing env variable using `+=`.
By splitting this variable into two variables you're making things more obscure and harder to follow while gaining nothing.
Yes, it can use some refactoring, but it's high-cost and low-gain. Something for rainy days with nothing serious to fix/set up.
Fair.

So the issue is clear: `errSecInternalComponent` is caused by `codesign` trying to open a UI prompt to unlock the keychain and being unable to due to CI job running headless, without UI.

Based on [a comment](https://github.com/fastlane/fastlane/issues/15185#issuecomment-577876643) in an issue I opened for fastlane I found this command:
```
security set-key-partition-list -S apple-tool:,apple: -s -k keychainPass keychainName
```
Source: https://stackoverflow.com/a/40039594

This is worth a try.

I tried it on our keychain and didn't change the `md5` hash of the keychain:
```sh
administrator@macos-03.ms-eu-dublin.ci.misc:~ % md5 nim-status-client.keychain-db    
MD5 (nim-status-client.keychain-db) = 3bd9d4c85e4702236317a7535abb41bd

administrator@macos-03.ms-eu-dublin.ci.misc:~ % security set-key-partition-list -S apple-tool:,apple: -s -k ${KEYCHAIN_PASS} nim-status-client.keychain-db
...

administrator@macos-03.ms-eu-dublin.ci.misc:~ % md5 nim-status-client.keychain-db                                                                         
MD5 (nim-status-client.keychain-db) = 3bd9d4c85e4702236317a7535abb41bd
```
